content: Sarah is a PhD student studying social psychology at the University of Oregon. She studies how people form moral character judgments of others and how those judgments change (or fail to change) over time.
summary: Sarah is a PhD student studying social psychology at the University of Oregon. She studies how people form moral character judgments of others and how those judgments change (or fail to change) over time.
title: Sarah Dimakis

content: Cameron is a doctoral candidate studying personality and social psychology at the University of Oregon. He is interested in incorporating new technologies and methodologies into the study of psychology. He is the creator and maintainer of the R packages panoply, iccImpact, and merlinmann as well as the outRun RStudio Editor Theme.
summary: Cameron is a doctoral candidate studying personality and social psychology at the University of Oregon. He is interested in incorporating new technologies and methodologies into the study of psychology. He is the creator and maintainer of the R packages panoply, iccImpact, and merlinmann as well as the outRun RStudio Editor Theme.

content:
Learning R can feel intimidating, and getting started is often the hardest part. Learning a few basics can go a long way and empower you to take the next step. And, even if you‚Äôve been using R for a while, you can almost always learn something new and useful when going back over the fundamentals.
Slidesfitvids('.shareagain', {players: 'iframe'});
Further ReadingGetting Started with Data in R (chapter from ModernDive)
A GIF-based introduction to RStudio
Tour of RStudio from R-Ladies Sydney
title: Basics of R, RStudio, & R Markdown

content: Papers  Brehmer M, Sedlmair M, Ingram S, Munzner T. Visualizing Dimensionally-reduced Data: Interviews with Analysts and a Characterization of Task Sequences. Proc. Beyond Time & Errors: Novel Evaluation Methods For Information Visualization (BELIV) 2014. p. 1‚Äì8. Borland D, Taylor MR. Rainbow color map (still) considered harmful. IEEE computer graphics and applications. 2007 Mar;27(2):14‚Äì7. Christensen DL, Baio J, Van Naarden Braun K, Bilder D, Charles J, Constantino JN, et al. Prevalence and Characteristics of Autism Spectrum Disorder Among Children Aged 8 Years–Autism and Developmental Disabilities Monitoring Network, 11 Sites, United States, 2012. MMWR Surveillance summaries : Morbidity and mortality weekly report Surveillance summaries / CDC. 2016 Apr 1;65(3):1‚Äì23. Cleveland WS, McGill R. Graphical Perception: Theory, Experimentation, and Application to the Development of Graphical Methods. Journal of the American Statistical Association. 1984;79(387):531‚Äì54. Cleveland WS, Diaconis P, McGill R. Variables on Scatterplots Look More Highly Correlated When the Scales Are Increased. Science; 1982;216(4550):1138‚Äì41. D√∂rk M, Feng P, Collins C, Carpendale S. Critical InfoVis: exploring the politics of visualization. Proc. ‘CHI 2013. Elliott, K. “39 studies about human perception in 30 minutes”; presented at OpenVis 2016. Heer J, Bostock M. Crowdsourcing graphical perception: using mechanical turk to assess visualization design. ACM CHI ‘10; 2010. p. 203‚Äì12. Kosara R. An Empire Built On Sand: Reexamining What We Think We Know About Visualization. in the Proceedings of the Sixth Workshop on Beyond Time and Errors on Novel Evaluation Methods for Visualization (BELIV ‘16) 2016. p. 162‚Äì8. Krzywinski M, Altman N. Points of significance: error bars. Nat Meth. Nature Research; 2013 Oct;10(10):921‚Äì2. Krzywinski M, Altman N. Visualizing samples with box plots. Nat Meth. 2014 Feb;11(2):119‚Äì20. Shneiderman B. Research agenda: Visual overviews for exploratory search. Information Seeking Support Systems. 2008;11:4. Sedlmair M, Meyer M, Munzner T. Design Study Methodology: Reflections from the Trenches and the Stacks. IEEE Transactions on Visualization and Computer Graphics. 2012 Dec;18(12):2431‚Äì40. Sedlmair M, Tatu A, Munzner T, Tory M. A Taxonomy of Visual Cluster Separation Factors. Computer Graphics Forum. 2012;31(3pt4):1335‚Äì44. Sedlmair M, Munzner T, Tory M. Empirical Guidance on Scatterplot and Dimension Reduction Technique Choices. IEEE Transactions on Visualization and Computer Graphics. 2013 Dec;19(12):2634‚Äì43. Weissgerber TL, Milic NM, Winham SJ, Garovic VD. Beyond bar and line graphs: time for a new data presentation paradigm. PLoS Biol. Public Library of Science; 2015 Apr;13(4):e1002128.  Blog posts, etc.  The Why Axis’s “Mind the Gap: An Economic Chart Remake”, by Jon Schwabish Notes on the Arabic FedEx logo. Jenny Cham’s delightful “sketchnotes” from a 2014 seminar by the incomparable Tamara Munzner. Randy Olson’s illustration of Small Multiples vs. Animated GIFs. Visual.ly’s Color Emotion Guide I am very interested in William Playfair and the history of data visualization:  Atlas Obscura, The Scottish Scoundrel Who Changed How We See Data Lauren Klein, Repairing William Playfair at the MLA Georgia Tech’s Digital Humanities Lab, Repairing William Playfair   Neil Richards, When is a visualisation a call to action? Carl Zimmer (yes, the Carl Zimmer) on genome graphs: As DNA reveals its secrets, scientists are assembling a new picture of humanity, with numerous examples of creative new ways to visualize genetic variation. Ben Jones, “From Simple Tables to Multiple Vizzes”: an illustration of ten different ways to visualize the same table. What different stories pop out from the different visualizations? Kristoffer Magnusson, How to tell when error bars correspond to a significant p-value Kyle Walker, Should you visualize data with a map or a chart? Thoughts from teaching introductory geography Lazaro Gamio (Washington Post), Election maps are telling you big lies about small things Cartonerd, The NYT election map vis4.net, Why we didn‚Äôt use a cartogram in the Brexit map Benjamin Hennig, Cartogram Special ‚Äì Brexit Tom Pearson (Financial Times), Communicating with data ‚Äî How the FT explained Brexit: “From early sketch to final dashboard, FT data visualisation experts explain the process”
summary: Papers  Brehmer M, Sedlmair M, Ingram S, Munzner T. Visualizing Dimensionally-reduced Data: Interviews with Analysts and a Characterization of Task Sequences. Proc. Beyond Time & Errors: Novel Evaluation Methods For Information Visualization (BELIV) 2014.
title: Useful readings

content: Visualising Data’s “Resources” index Matt Brehmer’s Monster List Of Resources (from UBC) OHSU Communications Office (Graphic Design services, etc.) HelpMeViz (crowdsourced data visualization help)  Blogs  The Functional Art FlowingData The Why Axis eagereyes Visua.ly’s blog Junk Charts WTF Visualizations setosa.io (nifty d3 demos!)  References & Examples  R Graph Compendia/Catalogs: A Compendium of Clean Graphs in R, by Eric-Jan Wagenmakers and Quentin F. Gronau (note: in “Base R”) R Graph Catalog, by Joanna Zhao and Jennifer Bryan (note: in ggplot2) Markdown Tutorial Summer 2016 ggplot OHSU Data Jamboree A useful tutorial on using the Seaborn Python library for visualizing distributions. A Dramatic Tour through Python‚Äôs Data Visualization Landscape (including ggplot and Altair) The Washington Post’s “demographic tug-of-war” visualization is a lovely illustration of how not to appropriately use color saturation and hue to encode information, and also has misleading axes (both in unit spacing and direction)! The New York Times' interactive “The 1,024 Ways Clinton or Trump Can Win the Election” is a great use of interactivity as a data exploration tool. Also from the NYT, “Your Surgeon Is Probably a Republican, Your Psychiatrist Probably a Democrat” makes excellent use of a graphs and charts to tell a very clear story. Also note their detailed description at the end of the article of how the data were collected! The Washington Post’s “One Hundred Years of Hurricanes” is a nice example of small-multiples cartography along with color. The New York Times' “What Good Marathons and Bad Investments Have in Common” illustrates a good use of contrast and preattentive processing (plus is a very interesting story!). From Our World In Data, a nice example of using color and saturation to highlight certain information, in a terrifying plot about Life Expectancy vs. Health Expenditure Over Time. Myriahedral map projections are interesting. Tilegrams are a good alternative to a cartogram. We do not recommend making bivariate chloropleth maps, but if you must, here’s a good tutorial on how to do it and what some of the considerations are.  Resources & Tools  ColorBrewer Adobe Kuler Colorgorical Photochrome Lyra Packages:  janitor Vincent (Python-to-Vega generation library) mpld3, an implementation of matplotlib on top of d3.js.
summary: Visualising Data’s “Resources” index Matt Brehmer’s Monster List Of Resources (from UBC) OHSU Communications Office (Graphic Design services, etc.) HelpMeViz (crowdsourced data visualization help)  Blogs  The Functional Art FlowingData The Why Axis eagereyes Visua.
title: Useful websites

content:
Data comes in many different shapes and sizes, which means we need a way to represent different kinds of data in R in order to distinguish them. Today, we‚Äôre going to cover the different fundamental types of data in R and give you a feel for different ways that data can be structured and indexed.
Slidesfitvids('.shareagain', {players: 'iframe'});
Further ReadingR for Data Science Ch 20: Vectors
This tutorial by Jenny Bryan
title: Data Types & Structures

content:
Functions are the ‚Äúverbs‚Äù of R‚Äîthey allow you to actually do interesting things with your data. We will cover the basics of how to use functions in R, how to get access to different functions by downloading packages, some general principles for what to do when you run into problems.
Slidesfitvids('.shareagain', {players: 'iframe'});
Further ReadingHow to read an R help page by Kieran Healy
‚ÄúObject of type ‚Äòclosure‚Äô is not subsettable‚Äù, keynote talk by Jenny Bryan at rstudio::conf(2020)
Deep dive into debugging by Jim Hester
title: Functions, Packages, & Debugging

content:
Before we get started importing, wrangling, tidying, and visualizing data, we should talk about a powerful tool for chaining functions together: pipes.
Slidesfitvids('.shareagain', {players: 'iframe'});
Further ReadingR for Data Science Ch 18: Pipes
Summary of Magrittr from tidyverse.org
title: Piping

content:
So far we have been using functions in base R. Now we‚Äôre going to take a first look at the tidyverse‚Äîa widely used framework for doing the full spectrum of data analysis, from importing to cleaning, visualizing, and modelling data.
Slidesfitvids('.shareagain', {players: 'iframe'});
Further ReadingOverview of tidyverse core packages
Learning resources from tidyverse.org
Welcome to the tidyverse (a short article)
title: Introduction to the Tidyverse

content:
The first step of any data analysis workflow is to get data into R. This isn‚Äôt always as straightforward as you might think, but, fortunately, there are some core functions that make this easy and efficient. Since we are starting at the beginning, we will also discuss the idea of a project-oriented workflow, which is a way to keep an organized and consistent process whenever you work with data in R that will also make your work reproducible and shareable. And the decisions you make right at the start of a data analysis project‚Äîeven before importing your data‚Äîwill have a lot of down-stream consequences.
Slidesfitvids('.shareagain', {players: 'iframe'});
Further ReadingR for Data Science Ch 8: Project-oriented workflow
Why Jenny Bryan will come set your computer on fire üî• if you use setwd().
How to use the here package by Jenny Richmond
title: Importing Data & Project-Oriented Workflows

content:
When you are given data to analyze, it will almost always be in a format that makes it hard to create visualizations, perform modelling, and generate tables. In other words, most of the time, it will need to be wrangled into the correct format. The dplyr package has a very powerful set of functions for doing just this. Today we will be covering the core dplyr ‚Äúverbs‚Äù that allow you to transform your data with optimal specificity and efficiency.
Slidesfitvids('.shareagain', {players: 'iframe'});
Further ReadingR for Data Science chapter on data transformation
Tutorial on tidyselect by Ted Laderas
Flipbooks on data wrangling and summarizing by Gina Reynolds
title: Data Wrangling with {dplyr}

content:
The concept of tidy data is, as the name suggests, of primary importance in the tidyverse. This lesson will introduce you to the criteria of tidy data, why it‚Äôs important, and how to reshape your raw data into a tidy format using pivot_wider() and pivot_longer().
Slidesfitvids('.shareagain', {players: 'iframe'});
Further ReadingR for Data Science chapter on tidy data
Tutorial on reshaping data from R-LadiesSydney
title: Data Tidying with {tidyr}

content:
Data visualization is at the very core of science. In order to understand and glean insights from our data, we need different ways of representing it visually. R has an incredible capacity for creating all sorts of plots, charts, and tables, and today we will only scratch the surface. We will discuss the fundamentals of the powerful ggplot2 package and the ‚Äúgrammar of graphics‚Äù that underlies it.
Slidesfitvids('.shareagain', {players: 'iframe'});
Further ReadingR for Data Science chapter on data visualization
Modern Dive chapter on data visualization
Cookbook for R chapter on data visualization
ggplot2: Elegant Graphics for Data Analysis
the ggplot flipbook by Gina Reynolds‚Äîshows how to create plots line-by-line
title: Data Visualization with {ggplot2}
R Tips & Tricks

content:
Hello! Welcome to the 5th Annual UO R Bootcamp. There are a few things we‚Äôd like you to do before we get started to make things run as smoothly as possible.
If possible, please try to complete this checklist before the first UO R Bootcamp session. Thank you!

Register for the UO R Bootcamp by completing this short registration survey. If you can‚Äôt make all of the days (or all of the sessions on a given day), that‚Äôs okay! We just ask that you register so that we can (1) send you the links to join the Zoom sessions and (2) get a better understanding of your familiarity with R. Registration is, of course, free.
Make sure you have a Zoom account set up through the University of Oregon. We will use the same Zoom link for each day of the bootcamp. You will receive the link through email and slack.
Join the Slack workspace. This is how we will primarily be communicating with each other, and it is the best place to ask questions outside of the scheduled bootcamp hours. We‚Äôll be using the channel #bootcamp2022. You should have received an email invitation to join the SlackRs workspace. If you haven‚Äôt received an invitation, send Cameron an email at ckay@uoregon.edu. When you join, please introduce yourself and say hello in the #bootcamp2022 channel!
Download and install both R and RStudio. R is free and, for the purposes of the bootcamp, you will only need the free version of RStudio. If you have any trouble downloading or opening R or RStudio, please let one of the UO R Bootcamp team members know, and we will do our best to help you solve the issue.
Download the exercises for the UO R Bootcamp. We will be working through the materials and exercises together during the bootcamp.
Review the Code of Conduct.
Optional - Download Google Chrome if you don‚Äôt have it already. The materials on this website are best viewed with Chrome. We‚Äôve found that using other browsers (e.g., Firefox, Safari) can lead to some technical difficulties.
Looking forward to seeing you all soon. Hopefully we‚Äôll have you loving R in no time!
-The UO R Bootcamp Team
summary: Hello! Welcome to the 5th Annual UO R Bootcamp. There are a few things we‚Äôd like you to do before we get started to make things run as smoothly as possible.
title: Prework

content:
BooksWebsitesInteractive tutorialsOnline communitiesUniversity of OregonBelow is a curated list of resources we‚Äôve found to be particularly useful and accessible. If you come across other great resources that you think you should be on this list, please let us know!

BooksR for Data Science‚Äîthorough and accessible, includes exercises and community-contributed solutions
Modern Dive‚Äîgreat for complete beginners, more focused on stats and modelling
The Tidyverse Style Guide‚Äîfor getting into the habit of using best practices early on
Big Book of R‚Äîa collection of pretty much any R-related book that‚Äôs out there (categorized by topic and searchable)

WebsitesRStudio Education‚Äôs learning resources and blog‚Äîa veritable treasure trove!
RStudio cheatsheets‚Äîworth printing ones you commonly use
tidyverse.org‚Äîlinks to learning resources, package documentation, and a great blog to stay up to date
learnr4free‚Äîa searchable site for all sorts of learning resources

Interactive tutorialsRBootcamp‚Äîa free online course about the basics of the tidyverse
RStudio primers‚Äîthese, along with other tutorials, can also be run in the Tutorial pane in the RStudio IDE
Teacup Giraffes‚Äîmore stats focused, with incredible artwork and adorable tiny giraffes ü¶í

Online communitiesR for Data Science Online Learning Community‚Äîsuper friendly and welcoming to R users at all levels
#rstats Twitter‚Äîalso very friendly and inclusive (despite being Twitter). Good advice on this here
Tidy Tuesday‚Äîa weekly community-based data viz challenge on Twitter. Great for hands-on, self-directed practice!
RStudio Community‚Äîgreat for asking for help from knowledgable experts

University of Oregon5-course Educational Data Science Specialization offered by UO College of Education. See course websites here and info sheet below. Cannot recommend highly enough! ‚≠ê ‚≠ê ‚≠ê ‚≠ê ‚≠ê
UO Psych Data Analysis Sequence (PSY611, PSY612, PSY613), led by Sara Weston and Elliot Berkman. See course websites here‚Äîyou will learn a TON.
UO Libraries Data Services Department offers free one-on-one support for R and statistics, as well as free R workshops. Every Friday at noon, they also host Coffee + Data && Code in the DREAM Lab, providing an opportunity to learn from your peers and share your latest coding challenges and victories. ‚òï
SlackRs workspace‚Äîuse this to ask for help from other UO community members when you‚Äôre stuck on something or need some advice.
Each other! As grad students, one of the best resources you have access to is your peers. You can read more of Brendan Cullen‚Äôs thoughts about this here. When in doubt, ask for help‚Äîand pay it forward if/whenever you can. ‚ù§Ô∏è
summary: BooksWebsitesInteractive tutorialsOnline communitiesUniversity of OregonBelow is a curated list of resources we‚Äôve found to be particularly useful and accessible. If you come across other great resources that you think you should be on this list, please let us know!
title: Resources
